user.biography: National Geographic Explorer and NY Times photographer, creating an aerial perspective on climate change and global food supply @feedtheplanet

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by George Steinmetz on July 19, 2021. May be an image of standing.

node.text:
Al Ain Dairy, in Abu Dhabi, the world’s first commercial dairy for camel milk, which produces full cream camel milk and camel milk powder for the Gulf market.  Their 1,500 camels need three times as many years as cows to start producing milk, and three times as long between births, making their Camelait a prized commodity at 3x the price.  Unlike Al Ain’s herd of Holsteins, the dromedaries aren’t fussy feeders, or need air conditioning in the desert heat. 

If you want to hear more about my @FeedThePlanet project, I will be on a live stream interview with @AJStream today at 4:30 EDT.

location.name: Al Ain City, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

node.text: My wingman Alain Arnoux, as we shared an epic flight over the Dasht-e Kavir, Iran. This inhospitable basin is filled with the tops of ancient salt deposits that have risen to the surface as the salt is less dense than the overlying sediments. The result is a spectacular scene of geological chaos found nowhere else in the world.  It took a lot of work and a little luck for me, an American pilot to get permission to fly my own aircraft in the Islamic Republic, but fortune favors the bold.  From #DesertAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.

node.text:
Terraced fields of Pu’er tea being hand picked in Yunnan, China.  After harvest the leaves are dried and then wetted to ferment, before being compressed into bricks and dried again for transport.  Pu’er tea was a staple of Tea-Horse Road, a network of paths used to carry it across the Tibetan Plateau to Bengal by both foot and hoof.  The loads of precious tea often exceeded the weight of the porters that carried it.

This picture was taken in 2006 by motorized paraglider, after a running take-off from a road we had to block off with our 4x4s. The police were not amused…

node.text: Potato harvest in the Peruvian Andes, on a patchwork of family fields planted with potatoes, wheat, and quinoa.  The dominant crop here are the brightly colored varieties of quinoa that have become the big cash crop of the Andes, with their diversity adapted to different altitudes, soils, and climate.

node.text:
Abandoned grain elevators on the rail line that was once the economic core of Rapelje, MT. 

Eastern Montana has undergone extreme depopulation and land consolidation over the past century as mechanization has allowed farming on larger plots with less labor.  The first farmers in this area came under the Homestead act of 1909, which gave 320 acres for free to those who could farm the land for five years. Today Rapelje has a post office but no stores.  The K-12 school serves some seventy students from town and surrounding farms.  In the background of the second view is the town’s only new house.

node.text:
Abandoned grain elevator at Sipple, that was once used to store wagon loads of wheat before loading on to rail cars crossing the semi-arid plains of Eastern Montana. 

This area has undergone severe depopulation over the past century as mechanization has allowed farming on larger plots with less labor.  Most of the first farmers came here under the Homestead act of 1909, which gave the deed to 320 aces for free if you farmed the land for five years.  At that time there were 72 family homesteads per 36 sq mi, but now these same areas have less than a dozen people.

node.text: Fisher folk gather sockeye salmon from shore-based nets at low tide in the mouth of the Naknek River, Alaska.  For those lucky enough to have a seasonal permit, this is a cherished way to return to a simpler life, and make living each  summer with friends and family.  #sustainability #artisanal #pebblemine

node.text: Drift net fishing boats line up to offload their morning catch of sockeye salmon to a mother ship in the mouth of the Egegik River, Alaska.  The fishery here is tightly managed by the Alaska Fish and Game biologists, who turn the fishing season on and off multiple times each day after a sustainable amount of fish have passed their monitoring stations up river.  This is the peak of the biggest wild salmon run on earth.  #BristolBay #pebblemine #LastFrontier

node.text: Fishermen looking for fish escaping their net on a coral reef in the Quirimba Islands of Mozambique.  Two dhows and twenty men were working together at low tide, but their catch was small, and they could only lay two nets in a morning before the winds pick up and the sea becomes too rough.  Over fishing has cleaned out this once abundant fishery, and is forcing the locals into increasingly desperate attempts to earn a living from the sea.

node.text: Sailing dhow with villagers looking for reef fish at low tide in the Quirimba Islands, Mozambique.  The crystal clear waters belie the sad fact that this coastal ecosystem has been heavily over fished by the locals using increasingly finer nets, leaving very little to support their families.  It’s a remote and beautiful place, but you can’t eat beauty.

node.text: Ounianga Serir, a natural spring that has been turned into a salt lake by the desert winds of Northern Chad.  The Ounianga Lakes are a rare surface expression of the fresh water aquifer that underlies much of the Central Sahara.  Maps from aerial surveys in 1954 show the lakes were once larger and inter-connected, indicating that the water level has dropped. From #DesertAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.

node.text: Star-shaped fort of São João, Ibo Island, Mozambique.  The area was visited by Arab traders for centuries before Vasco da Gama landed here in 1502 to claim it for Portugal.  The fort was built in the 17th Century, and later used to house enslaved people being sold to French sugar plantations on Mauritius.
